overview_of_class:
This course is intended to help students improve their writing and use that writing to gain a deeper understanding of ethical decision-making. Students will learn techniques for writing effective narrative, reflective, persuasive, and research essays. These techniques include the effective use of specific details to engage and persuade readers, methods of organization that enable readers to follow your line of thinking easily, and strategies for editing sentences for clarity and conciseness. For the research essay, each student will be able to choose an ethics-related topic from fields including science, medicine, law, politics, sports, journalism, religion, engineering, business and others.

PROJECTS:

Students will draft and revise four essays:
Personal narrative about an ethical decision;
Reflective essay responding to Simon Wiesenthal's memoir: The Sunflower: On the possibilities and Limits of Forgiveness;
Persuasive essay that argues your position on an ethical controversy;
Research essay on an ethical issue of your choice.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion is the primary teaching method. Students will also meet with the instructor individually outside of class throughout the quarter to discuss their papers.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The writing assignments comprise 85% of the course grade. Class discussion comprises 15% of the grade.
